remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Good morning, thank you for coming in today. I understand you have been experiencing symptoms of dizziness and stumbling—can you tell me more about when these symptoms started and how often they occur?

remedi_labels.value: Good morning, thank you for coming in today.

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Good morning, doctor. Um, yes, I’ve been having a lot of dizziness lately, and I seem to stumble more than usual. It’s been going on for a little while now, but it feels like it’s getting worse. I’m also noticing some worsening shortness of breath. I’m just… I guess I’m a bit anxious about all of this.

I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—these symptoms can be concerning, and I appreciate you sharing them with me. You mentioned stumbling and dizziness; have you also experienced any episodes of garbled speech or difficulty finding words during this time?

remedi_labels.value: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—these symptoms can be concerning, and I appreciate you sharing them with me.
episodes of garbled speech or difficulty finding words

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… I guess my main concern is really the dizziness and the stumbling, but I have noticed some chest pain too. I’m not sure if that’s related or not.

Thank you for letting me know about your dizziness, stumbling, and chest pain—these are important symptoms to discuss. To help with my assessment, have you experienced any numbness or tingling in your face, arms, or legs, or any episodes of garbled speech recently?

remedi_labels.value: numbness or tingling in face, arms, or legs

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um, yes, actually… now that you mention it, I have had some numbness, mostly in my left arm and a bit in my face. And there was a time when my speech got kind of garbled—my words just wouldn’t come out right. It didn’t last too long, but it was scary. I wasn’t sure if it was something serious or maybe just part of the dizziness and stumbling I’ve been having. Should I be worried about these symptoms?

remedi_labels.value: Should I be worried about these symptoms?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried—experiencing numbness, garbled speech, and chest pain can be very unsettling. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any fevers or chills along with these neurological symptoms?

Let me think… actually, yes, I have had some fevers and chills here and there. I didn’t really connect them to the other symptoms before, but now that you ask, they have been happening around the same time as the numbness and the garbled speech. I’m just feeling more anxious about all of this now—should I be doing something different?

remedi_labels.value: should I be doing something different

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—these symptoms, especially when they occur together, can be quite concerning. To help with my assessment, have your symptoms of numbness, garbled speech, or chest pain ever occurred suddenly, or do they tend to come on gradually?

Well, um… let me think. The numbness and the garbled speech—those seemed to come on pretty suddenly, actually. It wasn’t like a slow thing; it just kind of happened all at once. The chest pain is a bit different—it sort of comes and goes, sometimes with the shortness of breath. And, like I mentioned, I do get fevers and chills off and on, but I didn’t really link them to these other symptoms before. I’m honestly just worried because it feels like a lot is happening at once.

I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with these symptoms happening all at once. To help guide my assessment, have you noticed any changes in your vision—such as double vision, blurred vision, or loss of vision—when these neurological symptoms occur?

remedi_labels.value: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with these symptoms happening all at once.
changes in vision such as double vision, blurred vision, or loss of vision when neurological symptoms occur

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Actually, yes, now that you mention it, I have had some blurred vision a couple of times when the dizziness and numbness started. It didn’t last very long, but it was definitely noticeable—almost like symptoms went fuzzy for a few minutes. I haven’t had double vision or lost my vision completely, but the blurriness was enough to make me sit down until it passed.

Is it normal for all these symptoms—like the blurred vision, numbness, and garbled speech—to happen together? Should I be concerned that it might be something serious with my skull base malformation or the encephalocele?

remedi_labels.value: blurred vision, numbness, and garbled speech happening together
concern about skull base malformation or encephalocele being serious

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially given your medical history of skull base malformation and encephalocele. To help with my assessment, have you noticed any recent changes in your ability to move your arms or legs, such as weakness or difficulty with coordination, during these episodes?

remedi_labels.value: recent changes in ability to move arms or legs, such as weakness or difficulty with coordination

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Yes, actually, I have noticed some weakness, mostly in my left arm and leg. It’s not all the time, but during those episodes—when I get the dizziness, numbness, and blurred vision—I feel like it’s harder to move that side, and sometimes I feel a bit unsteady on my feet. The coordination just isn’t what it used to be, especially when everything seems to come on at once.

I know my history with the complex bony skull base malformation and the encephalocele makes symptoms more complicated. Is it possible that these symptoms—like the sudden weakness, garbled speech, and blurred vision—are related to that? Or could it be something else entirely? Should I be worried about a stroke or something similar?

remedi_labels.value: weakness in left arm and leg
Are these symptoms related to my skull base malformation or encephalocele?
Could it be something else entirely?
Should I be worried about a stroke or something similar?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially given your medical history and the sudden onset of neurological symptoms like weakness, garbled speech, and blurred vision. To help with my assessment, have you experienced any recent severe headaches, neck stiffness, or changes in your level of consciousness during these episodes?

remedi_labels.value: sudden onset of neurological symptoms like weakness, garbled speech, and blurred vision
changes in level of consciousness during episodes

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… yes, I have had some pretty severe headpains lately, especially when the other symptoms start up. They’re not like my usual headpains—they feel a lot more intense and come on kind of suddenly. I haven’t really noticed any neck stiffness, though. As for changes in my level of consciousness… I don’t think I’ve actually passed out, but there have been a couple of times where I felt really out of it—almost like I was in a fog or couldn’t focus properly.

I’m just getting more anxious with all these symptoms happening together. With my history of the skull base malformation and the encephalocele, should I be worried that something serious is going on? Is this something that needs urgent attention?

remedi_labels.value: episodes of feeling out of it or in a fog
should I be worried that something serious is going on
Is this something that needs urgent attention

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—experiencing sudden severe headaches, neurological symptoms like weakness, numbness, garbled speech, blurred vision, and changes in your level of alertness, especially with your medical history of skull base malformation and encephalocele, is understandably concerning. Based on your symptoms, I am concerned about the possibility of a neurological event such as a transient ischemic attack or stroke, or complications related to your underlying condition. Have you noticed any recent changes in your ability to swallow or any episodes of choking during these episodes?

remedi_labels.value: neurological symptoms like weakness, numbness, garbled speech, blurred vision, and changes in level of alertness
recent changes in ability to swallow or episodes of choking

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… now that you mention it, I have had a little trouble swallowing sometimes, especially when the other symptoms are happening. It’s not like I’m choking exactly, but it does feel harder to get symptoms down, and I have to be careful when I eat or drink. I haven’t had any full episodes of choking, but it’s definitely been more difficult than usual.

With everything you’re saying—about possible transient ischemic attack or stroke, and with my history of the skull base malformation and encephalocele—I’m honestly getting more worried. Should I be going to the hospital right away? Is this something that could get worse if I wait? I just want to make sure I’m not missing something serious.

remedi_labels.value: Should I be going to the hospital right away?
Is this something that could get worse if I wait?
I just want to make sure I’m not missing something serious.

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious, especially with the combination of sudden neurological symptoms—such as weakness, numbness, garbled speech, blurred vision, difficulty swallowing, and severe headaches—along with your medical history of skull base malformation and encephalocele. These symptoms are concerning for a possible acute neurological event or complication related to your underlying condition, and they do warrant urgent medical assessment. Have you experienced any recent loss of bladder or bowel control during these episodes?

recent loss of bladder or bowel control

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Well, um… I haven’t really lost control of my bladder or bowels, no. I do have to go to the bathroom a bit more often, but I haven’t had any accidents or anything like that during these episodes. 

I just… with all these symptoms happening together—like the sudden weakness, numbness, garbled speech, blurred vision, difficulty swallowing, and those severe headpains—I’m honestly really anxious. You mentioned a possible acute neurological event or a complication from my skull base malformation or encephalocele. Is there a way to know for sure what’s causing this? And if it is something like a stroke or a complication, what should I expect in terms of treatment or recovery? Should I be preparing for surgery sooner rather than later?

Based on your symptoms, my assessment is that you may be experiencing a significant neurological event or a complication related to your underlying condition, which requires urgent clinical evaluation and possibly imaging studies to determine the exact cause. Have you noticed any recent changes in your vision that are persistent, such as ongoing loss of vision or double vision, outside of the brief episodes of blurriness you described?

Thank you for explaining everything so clearly, doctor. Um, let me think… I haven’t had any ongoing loss of vision or double vision—just those brief episodes of blurred vision when the other symptoms start up. Most of the time, my eyesight goes back to normal after a few minutes. But it’s definitely scary when it happens.

I really appreciate you taking this seriously. With all these neurological symptoms—like the weakness, numbness, garbled speech, difficulty swallowing, and severe headpains—plus my history of skull base malformation and encephalocele, I’m just so anxious about what could be going on. 

Is there anything I should be doing right now while I wait for the imaging studies? Should I avoid certain activities or foods? And, um, if this turns out to be a complication from my encephalocele or something like a stroke, what kind of treatments or interventions should I expect? I just want to be as prepared as possible.
